questions.text: Patch test reading after how many days:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

48 hours and 96 hours Any individual suspected of having allergic contact dermatitis or atopic dermatitis needs patch testing. Reading of the patch test is taken after 48 hrs and 96 hrs, (best reading) and then on day 7 for late reactions due to metals, PPD, etc.

Highyeild:

Patch Test It is undertaken for investigation and confirmation of substances that produce Allergic contact dermatitis. Relies on the principle of type IV hypersensitivity reaction. Method: A series of allergens are applied to the back The allergens on the patch include latex, medications, preservatives, hair dyes, fragrances, resins, and various metals. It needs to stay for 2 to 4 days Positive result: shows erythema & papules or vesicles After 48 hours , the patch is removed and erythema is noted Another read is taken after 96 hours to check for any delayed reaction. Photopatch test Modification of patch test Done for photo allergen

Extraedge:

Important consideration for patch test Patch test should be delayed for 4 weeks after sunbathing Steroids should be stopped before test (but at doses <15 mg no effect of steroids on the test)

questions.text: Young HIV patient presents with recurrent lesions over genitals h/o contact with a commercial sex worker. What is the microscopy finding shown in the given below image?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intranuclear inclusion body The given history of the patient suggests the presence of Herpes . Genital herpes is a common, sexually transmitted disease that is caused by the herpes simplex viruses type 2 (HSV-2) > type 1 (HSV-1). Most genital herpes infections are caused by HSV-2. Herpes viruses are associated with intranuclear inclusion bodies: Cowdry bodies -eosinophilic ground-glass areas in the nucleus with margination of nuclear chromatin.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies: Seen in viral infections herpes simplex virus, cytomegalovirus, and rabies virus.Not specific to herpes Option C . BAC with bipolar staining: This is a characteristic finding seen in infections caused by Bartonella species, such as cat-scratch disease or trench fever. It is not seen in HSV infections. Option D. Multinucleated giant cells: This is a nonspecific finding that can be seen in various viral infections, including HSV infections.

Table:

#MANTRA Sexually Transmitted Diseases Syphilitic chancre ( Hard chancre ) Genital herpes Granuloma inguinale/ Donovanosis chancroid ( soft chancre ) Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) Causative organism Treponema pallidum HSV2> HSV1 Klebsiella granulomatas Haemophilus ducreyi Chlamydia trachomatis L1, L2, L3 Incubation periods 10 to 90 days (Avg 21 days) 2 to 7 days 8 to 80 days 1 to 14 days 10 to 14 days Ulcer feature Single, painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base. Painless, Beefy red granulomatousususus ulcer with rolled out margin Painful, punched out ulcer Painless Lymphadenapathy Painless Painful and pruritic Absent (Pseudobubos seen ) Painful Painful. Buboes ulcerates. Management Penicillin Acyclovir Azithromycin/ Doxycycline Azithromycin/ceftriaxone Doxycycline Special feature Ulcer bleeds on touch Ulcer bleeds on touch Groove sign is seen Inclusion bodies Intracytoplasmic Henderson peterson Molluscum (Pox virus) Negri bodies Rabies Guarneri bodies Vaccinia Paschen bodies Varicella Bollinger bodies Fowl pox Borrel bodies Fowl pox Intranuclear Cowdry A Herpes, yellow fever Cowdry B Adenovirus, poliovirus

questions.text: Chancre Redux is a clinical feature of
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Early relapsing syphilis Chancre Redux is a clinical feature of Early Relapsing Syphilis, which is a rare form of syphilis that occurs during the secondary stage. During the primary stage of syphilis , a painless ulcer called a chancre appears at the site of infection, which can be genitals, mouth, or rectum. During the secondary stage of syphilis , the infection spreads throughout the body and causes a variety of symptoms, including skin rash, fever, swollen lymph nodes, and sore throat. Early Relapsing Syphilis is a form of secondary syphilis that occurs when symptoms from the primary stage reappear, including a chancre.

Highyeild:

Etiology: Treponema pallidum Incubation period: 9 to 90 days Primary lesion: papules which progress to the genital ulcer (Hard chancre/ hunter Ian chancre) Single ulcer with clean base Induration present Nontender No bleeding on touch Inguinal lymph nodes: Bilaterally enlarged, non-tender, rubbery consistency Diagnosis: Dark field microscopy Secondary syphilis : Symmetric, non-pruritic, polymorphic rash over palms and soles Mucosal lesion: Condyloma Lata Snail track ulcer Latent & tertiary Syphilis- Gummatous syphilis: Rubbery nodules break to form ulcer with punched out the Treatment: Inj. Benzathine penicillin

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Chancroid : It is a bacterial infection that causes painful genital ulcers and is not associated with Chancre Redux. Option B. Recurrent herpes simplex virus: It is a viral infection that causes outbreaks of painful blisters or sores on or around the mouth or genitals, but it is not associated with Chancre Redux. Option C. Late syphilis: It is also known as tertiary syphilis, occurs several years after the initial infection and can cause serious health problems, such as damage to the heart, brain, nerves, and other organs. However, Late Syphilis does not typically cause a chancre or Chancre Redux.

Extraedge:

Features of secondary syphilis: Macular/Roseolar rash: Earliest rash Papular rash over palms and soles Late stage: Nummular rash Oral mucosa: Snail track lesion Condyloma lata Moth eaten alopecia Generalised lymphadenopathy

Table:

#MANTRA Sexually Transmitted Diseases Syphilitic chancre ( Hard chancre ) Genital herpes Granuloma inguinale/ Donovanosis chancroid ( soft chancre ) Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) Causative organism Treponema pallidum HSV2> HSV1 Klebsiella granulomatas Haemophilus ducreyi Chlamydia trachomatis L1, L2, L3 Incubation periods 10 to 90 days (Avg 21 days) 2 to 7 days 8 to 80 days 1 to 14 days 10 to 14 days Ulcer feature Single, painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base. Painless, Beefy red granulomataus ulcer with rolled out margin Painful, punched out ulcer Painless Lymphadenapathy Painless Painful and pruritic Absent (Pseudobubos seen ) Painful Painful. Buboes ulcerates. Management Penicillin Acyclovir Azithromycin/ Doxycycline Azithromycin/ceftriaxone Doxycycline Special feature Ulcer bleeds on touch Ulcer bleeds on touch Groove sign is seen

questions.text: Topical steroids are most effective in
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Eczematous dermatitis Eczematous dermatitis or Atopic dermatitis is a chronic disorder characterized by xerosis, pruritus, scaly erythematous patches, and thickening of the skin with the enhancement of normal skin markings (lichenification). Steroids are the drug of choice for eczematous dermatitis.

Highyeild:

Atopic dermatitis: It is classified as endogenous eczema triggered by exogenous agents. Key diagnostic criteria: Hanfin and Rajka Pruritus- hallmark Rash on face, extensors, or both in infants and young children Lichenification in flexural areas in older children Tendency toward chronic or chronically relapsing dermatitis Personal or family history of atopic disease: asthma, allergic rhinitis, atopic dermatitis Other Common Findings: Skin features: Dryness Ichthyosis Pityriasis alba White dermatographism (white line appears on the skin within 1 minute of being stroked with a blunt instrument) Head-light sign : the periorbital, perioral and perinasal area is spared Ocular features: Dennie-Morgan folds (accentuated lines or grooves below the margin of the lower eyelid) Allergic shiners (darkening beneath the eyes) Conjunctivitis Keratoconus Anterior subcapsular cataracts

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Dermal atrophy: Topical steroids can cause dermal atrophy with prolonged use, and hence are not considered effective in treating it. Option C . Bullous lesions due to HSV: Topical steroids are not the treatment of choice for bullous lesions due to HSV. Antiviral medications such as acyclovir or valacyclovir are the primary treatment for HSV infections. Option D . Rosea: Topical steroids are not effective in treating rosea, which is a self-limited viral rash. The treatment for rosea is typically symptomatic, focusing on the relief of itching.

questions.text: Which cell is not present in the shown layer:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Langerhans cells The arrow is pointing towards Stratum basale and Langerhans cells are most prominent in stratum spinosum and papillary dermis.

Highyeild:

Langerhans cells They constitute 3%–5% of the cells in this layer. Normally found scattered among keratinocytes of the stratum spinosum. Not connected to adjacent keratinocytes They are antigen-presenting cells that are derived from bone marrow Immunostains: CD1a or S-100 Rod-shaped organelle with vacuole at one end: tennis racquet shaped Ultra structurally, they are characterized by a folded nucleus and distinct intracytoplasmic organelles called Birbeck granules.

Table:

#MANTRA Cells of Epidermis Name Derived from Location Function Marker Keratinocytes Ectoderm Stratum spinosum. Originate in Stratum Basale Dominant cell of the epidermis, a major role in skin repair Langerhans cells Bone marrow Stratum spinosum Antigen presenting cell CD207, S100, CD1a Melanocytes Neural crest Stratum Basale Melanin production Melan A, HMB45, S100 Merkel cells Ectoderm Stratum Basale Mechanoreceptor Cytokeratin 20

questions.text: A Patient from Uttarakhand presented in September with fever and myalgia. Patient started on IV Ceftriaxone given but it didn't help, later noticed cutaneous lesions on examination (black eschar) in the axilla given below in the figure. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Scrub typhus The given clinical history of fever, headache, and body ache with a black eschar on the body surrounded by erythema is suggestive of Scrub typhus.

Highyeild:

Scrub typhus Cause: Orientia tsutsugamushi Vector: Trombiculid mite Features: Fever, headache, body aches and rash. Black eschar: Black scab surrounded by erythema Treatment: Drug of choice Doxycycline

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B . Anthrax: Also presents with black eschar which initially starts as a painless papule and progresses to form a malignant pustule. Since this is a zoonosis, there should be a history of handling infecting animals like sheep. Option C . Kyasanur disease: Do not form eschar. It is caused by the KFD virus and presents with sudden onset fever, headache, myalgia, and gastrointestinal disturbances. Option D . Dematiaceous fungi: These fungi are usually defined as having melanin or melanin-like pigment in the wall of their hyphae and/other spores and can cause superficial infection, myeloma, and phaeohyphomycosis.

Extraedge:

Differentials of Black eschar Cutaneous anthrax Scrub typhus Spider bite

questions.text: Arrange the following blisters in order from superficial to deep: Pemphigus vulgaris Epidermolysis bullosa dystrophicans Linear IgA Bullous pemphigoid Select the correct answer using the code below:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1 → 4 → 2 → 3 Pemphigus vulgaris → Bullous pemphigoid → Linear IgA → Epidermolysis bullosa dystrophic. Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune, intraepithelial, blistering disease affecting the skin and mucous membranes. It is mediated by circulating autoantibodies directed against keratinocyte cell surfaces. Bullous pemphigoid is a chronic, inflammatory, subepidermal , blistering disease. Linear immunoglobulin A (IgA) dermatosis (LAD) is an autoimmune subepidermal Vesiculobullous disease that may be idiopathic or drug-induced. Epidermolysis bullosa dystrophic: The deficiency in anchoring fibrils impairs the adherence between the epidermis and the underlying dermis. The skin of DEB patients is thus highly susceptible to severe blistering.

Highyeild:

Direct immunofluorescence findings in common bullous disorders Pemphigus Vulgaris Fishnet appearance- Epidermal intercellular deposits of C3 with a reticular pattern Pemphigus Foliaceus Fishnet appearance Bullous pemphigoid Linear deposits of IgG on the dermal-epidermal junction in bullous pemphigoid Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita Linear deposits of IgG on the dermal-epidermal junction zone, with a u-serrated pattern

questions.text: An 18-month child presents with fever and neck rigidity and the sign and symptoms are given below the image. Which of the following is the organism is the causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HSV type – 1 The given clinical picture is showing macules, Papules, vesicles that tand target lesions which is suggestive of erythema multiforme. The most common cause for the same is infection with herpes. Herpetic gingivostomatitis. Cause: HSV-1 Features: Vesicles that rupture to form erosions covered by membrane Associated with high-grade fever and constitutional symptoms More common in children Can be sexually transmitted/ direct contact HPE of mucosal Herpetic infection: Degeneration of stratified squamous epithelial cells Acantholysis Formation of an inflammatory infiltrate around capillaries of dermis Cowdry A bodies Complication: Dehydration Herpes labialis HSV encephalitis Herpetic whitlow Herpetic keratitis Eczema herpeticum Treatment: Acyclovir

Highyeild:

Herpes virus infection Virus - DNA Virus, multiply within the nucleus HSV-1 disease: Above diaphragm Orolabial herpes Herpetic gingivostomatitis Herpetic whitlow Erythema multiforme Eczema herpeticum Mollaret meningitis HSV-2 disease: Below diaphragm Genital herpes with bilateral enlarged and tender inguinal lymph nodes Primary lesions: Vesicles Multiple grouped tender ulcer Ulcers with polycyclic margins

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Variant of picornavirus: Picorna virus can causes aseptic meningitis, common cold, Conjunctivitis, herpangina and hand foot and mouth disease. Option C. Varicella zoster: Caused chicken pox with features of rash having dew drop on rose petal appearance Option D. Mycoplasma: Causes upper and lower respiratory tract infections in children and adults.

questions.text: A patient presented with joint pain and mild fever. NSAIDs prescribed by the doctor. Developed pigmentation after 1 week on the tip of the nose. What may be the condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chikungunya The given clinical scenario with centro- facial pigmentation involving the nose with history of fever, joint, and back pain is suggestive of the Chikungunya-chick sign.

Highyeild:

Chikungunya (CHK): Acute febrile illness accompanied by a rash, joint, and muscle pain caused by an arthropod-borne alphavirus. Vector: Aedes Mosquito Incubation periods: 4 to 7 days Features: sudden-onset high fever and chills followed by severe polyarthralgia . symmetrical involvement of several joints, especially the small joints of the hands and feet. arthralgia may persist for several months. Cutaneous features: An erythematous macular or maculopapular rash usually appears in the first 2–3 days of the illness and subsides within 7–10 days The rash may result in post-inflammatory macules or diffuse pigmentation. Pigmentation is most common on the face, characteristically affecting the nose : chick sign Treatment: Rehydration Topical emollients

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Melasma: It is a common acquired skin disorder that presents as a bilateral, blotchy, brownish facial pigmentation usually seen in women of age 20 to 40 years caused by photoaging. Option B. Dengue : Rash in dengue fever is a maculopapular or macular confluent rash over the face, thorax, and flexor surfaces, with islands of skin sparing. The rash typically begins on day 3 and persists for 2-3 days. A second rash may occur within 1-2 days of defervescence, lasting 1-5 days; it is morbilliform, is maculopapular, spares the palms and soles, and occasionally desquamates. Option D. Fixed drug eruption: It is a dermatological manifestation of drug reactions that often occur in the same location upon re-exposure to a drug. The hands and feet, eyelids, and anogenital areas are common sites. Lesions in the oral mucosa are usually found on the lips, tongue, and hard palate.
